social_posts.post_text:
#ad Blood. Reproductive Systems. Breast milk. Food. Non-human kin. Water. Microplastics are quite literally *everywhere*. Every day humans contribute to the problem by yes, consuming single use plastics at alarming and unsustainable rates- but also through washing synthetic clothes, beauty products with plastic sparkles and glitter, and body cleansers with plastic scrubbing beads (and so much more), which are all releasing microplastics into our waterways. 

There is currently a cool “micro” way to learn about microplastics at @yorkuniversity. York University is conducting research seeking to provide scientific evidence to support environmental policies in what is currently Canada and beyond. In an effort to catalyse positive change, York University is hosting the first-ever microlecture to educate about the impacts of microplastics. You can watch the microlecture via the link in my biography. 

@ancestorsfuture @royalchukz, who has a background in chemistry, speaks about our need to honour plastic, and in several speeches I’ve witnessed him breakdown how the absence of *respect* for this human innovation has contributed to our reckless consumption. This relatively simple concept has totally shifted my understanding of plastic, and has helped me appreciate that addressing the macro issue of microplastic equally requires a shift of worldview and regulations alongside technological development.

I don’t know the first thing about the chemical composition of plastics, or anything useful to the invention of plastic-alternatives; but, I do have a passion for shifting worldviews and policies through education and skill development! And the more I learn about microplastics, the more inclined I am to understand how my work can align with addressing the driving forces behind our over-reliance on plastics.

Photo: @roseandrangephotography

#YUpositivechange #microplastic #microplastics #YorkUniversity #YorkU

@woodscanada outfitted the 1982 Canadian Everest Expedition Team with tents, sleeping bags, packs, and down parkas as they became the first people from Canada to stand on the 8,848-meter peak of Mount Everest.

The WOODS EVEREST '82 COLLECTION honours the 40th
anniversary of this milestone with a capsule that is made in Canada (with imported materials) and inspired by the iconic styles, colours, and logos
from the 1982 expedition.

The set I’m sporting and more are available at @sportchek and @atmooutdoor.

#WoodsEverest82 #WoodsExplorer #sponsored

📷: @roseandrangephoto

As I usually say, I only work with less than 10% of the influencer contracts I receive. When I consider a contract, I do my best in critical background research on the brand and their product supply chain. I was impressed by WOODS’ track record, and particularly by their ethical sourcing of this line’s materials. When exploring the materials used in the Everest ‘82 capsule, I came across “600 Fill Power ALLIED Feather + Down™ Insulation”. 

What the hell does that mean? Who is ALLIED? So I went to the ALLIED website. In 2013, ALLIED (alliedfeather.com) led the creation of an industry wide standard - The Responsible Down Standard, centring Brambell’s five freedoms of animal welfare.

Their commitment to working with animal welfare groups and making sustainable, ethical manufacturing  practices scaleable is incredibly well reflected on their website and by their community partners. I got to a point of understanding before signing my contract with WOODS that their products still align with how I relate to veganism (see the link in my bio for more), and I’ve saved the ALLIED website as an example of transparency and accountability I’d like to emulate through my own work.

You can pick up the Canadian-made Everest ‘82 line at @sportchek and @atmooutdoor.

#WoodsEverest82 #WoodsExplorer #sponsored

Working on contracts with a photographer as an accessibility practice👇🏽

If you do paid social media content and you also navigate disabilities, I recommend that you ✨highly✨ consider including costs for a professional photographer. A few things I’ve done:

📸: Build a relationship with a photographer. Being able to go to one who knows your angles, how you work, and how to edit your skin tone (Caitlin literally has a custom filter for me now), will result in a more fun and easier time for you and the photographer. It also gives the chance for both of you to learn how to respect each other when working together.

📸: Include photography pricing in your pricing packages: “Every social media influencer contract will include pricing for a professional photographer to oversee the shooting and editing of content. Our preferred photographer is Rose and Range Photography; their Basic Package is included in our estimates. To see their other pricing packages, click here.”

📸: Include photography pricing in your estimate, and DON’T FORGET to include their taxes, and rushed processing fees. Depending on the photographer, include on your itemized estimate the number of photos they’ll get: “Rose and Range Photography, Basic Package, Rushed Order (10-15 professionally edited photos)”

📸: If relevant, explain to your client that this is a non-negotiable accessibility mechanism: “The Estimate includes a budget for a photographer; we started including this cost last year in other influencer contracts as a means of accessibility for me. This will accompany any media deliverables, even when the request is self-shot aesthetic.”

📸: Be prepared for some brands to say “no”, and consider the budget they may be working with. I don’t always try to pass these costs to the client, and I don’t always use a photographer if a great client honestly can’t afford it. And for the ones that can and still don’t want to pay, I’m prepared to let that opportunity pass me. Always try to consider the consequences of asserting your needs for respect and accessibility.

Hope this helps some of y’all.
As always, thank you to the incredible @roseandrangephoto ✨

My mission is not to convert the people around me to veganism. I love sharing my experience with veganism and what I’ve learned about the movement and industrialized food systems, and through this pathway of activism ✨I hope to invite others to consider their own relationship and journey to the food we consume✨.

I started my "What Veganism Means to Me" document at the beginning of my journey in April (an immediate transition to veganism) and I continue to update and expand the 11 page document. It includes a personal reflection, and then the research, resources, and reflection questions that have shaped my self-directed education. I’ve shared an excerpt from the document in this post, like…

🌱 Veganism means a lot of different things to different people, so I’ve taken time to reflect on and articulate what veganism means to me and how I relate to it.

🌱 No activist is shielded from perpetuating the harm I see in the vegan movement, regardless of their race or ethnic background… we must be critical of how we've all been conditioned as vessels of the living legacies of colonialism. 

🌱 I’ve grown up with teachings of reciprocity and respect when we exchange energy with animals, and because of this I do believe that this exchange can be ethical, natural, and honourable. 

🌱 I have committed my life and education to racial and climate justice activism, much of which has been relevant to vegan impetuses. My work is an extension of ‘self’ and because of this I am always navigating trauma and burnout, which means I have to honour my own boundaries for self-preservation.

When we're able to communicate a conscious and intentional relationship to food, we can invite others to do the same 😊🥙

(I’ve been seeing this play out, and it’s so cool 👆🏽 For example, I’ve started providing this document to clients when they ask for my dietary restrictions, and have had some change the whole conference meal plan to accommodate vegan options for everyone.)

Pictured chowing down on a vegan apple crumble Zy and I baked last night. Recipe from @that.veganbabe.

#vegan #veganism #veganfood #veganrecipes #vegansofig #veganlife

January 1, 2023 marks a full year of active and intentional acknowledgement of trauma, sexual healing, and relational learning and unlearning. I continue to be the happiest I’ve been in my life (see my January 1, 2022 post), and here are some of the ways I’ve seeded, nurtured, and protected this joy:

🌸 I experienced ethical non-monogamy and dating. The degree to which this requires the confrontation of ego, jealousy, possessiveness, and personal insecurities proved to be the discomfort I look for in my life. The communication of boundaries and expectations is a skill I was able to become so much more confident in, and it’s informed all of my relationships for the better. I find that I don’t have a preference between monogamy, ethical non-monogamy, or more casual arrangements, mostly because I’ve found joy in all these kinds of relationships.

🌸 I held space to process my emotions with a regular commitment of time and energy. I used mindmap journaling and audio notes to name my emotional reflexes when I felt triggered (hurt, upset) and left them for ~12 hrs. I’d then go back and process again with more reflection, and outside of the hormonal spikes that we go through in an intense emotional reflex. I was able to contribute to more self-aware and accountable conversations with myself and others.

🌸 I spoke more openly than ever about the sexual abuse and violence I’ve experienced in my life: I process what happened and how it’s affected me, put it into words, articulate my learnings, and then share with the hopes that it supports and validates someone else in pain.

🌸 While I’ve never actively hidden my bisexuality, I was more open about it. This was liberating.

🌸 A renewed and more conscious relationship to food as a result of becoming vegan so drastically affected my daily pain levels and pain flares that I feel like a completely different person.

🌸 I learned to apologize more openly and genuinely, a result of embracing the discomfort of when I mess up. This = more joy.

🌸 I invested more than I ever have in my non-romantic friendships (calls, quality time, gifting). I’ve never felt like I’ve had a more supportive circle of friends.

#NationalRibbonSkirtDay “My art is a testament to the beauty of sitting with and embracing pain. My art lives in moments of holistic healing.”

In 2021 I did a photo series with @mecohbain capturing my ribbon skirt art and the stories behind them.

I grew up learning how to sew, and actually got a few Fashion Studies scholarships in high school (but it wasn’t a passion of mine beyond moments of healing and connection). Sewing was always a way I connected with generations of women in my family, my ancestors, the future, and my own healing. Each skirt represents a significant moment of trauma in my life, where creating a ribbon skirt bridged my pain with healing.

I’ve made other ribbon skirts since this photo series was created, and will create a second volume when it feels right.

You can access the PDF in the link in my bio. Finally got around to putting this together.

On #NationalRibbonSkirtDay: “Jan. 4 is National Ribbon Skirt Day, a day where Indigenous women across the country are encouraged to wear their traditional regalia to celebrate their culture, their strength and their connection as women.

Sen. Mary Jane McCallum put forward a bill in Parliament to recognize National Ribbon Skirt Day in November 2021, and it received royal assent last month. McCallum said in a statement last month that the day is to "provide an opportunity for everyone in Canada to recognize, learn about, and celebrate the importance of Indigenous traditions and expressions of culture."” (@cbc)

The moderator actually tried pulling me down several times, but they cut out of frame her more overt efforts.

I was 23 in 2018 and that year after graduating university hit me like a tonne of bricks. I went from mostly student and youth run public speaking clients/conferences, to industry realities in my workplace and side contracts. Where my experiences had almost always been positive, I was now constantly being asked “are you in the right place” when registering as a speaker; confronted with too much surprise when I’d say “I’m a speaker”; interrupted; ignored. Navigating defending my right to be in those spaces, coupled with my very new journey with several disabilities in a very racist healthcare system, was crushing.

Last night when I wore this dress for my keynote, an older White woman and attendee came up to me and said “You don’t look like you belong here… you don’t look like you’re in business,” when I found myself at a business cocktail mixer. She had no information about me apart from how I look. And, she didn’t crush me. I’ve practiced bringing that onstage energy to my internal dialogue, and in doing so stand in my own power and value.

“This isn’t my most linear speech/panel, & that’s mostly because 1) although the other speaker’s cues had been respected, I wasn’t asked the question we had all confirmed & practiced, & 2) I was continuously interrupted by the other panel members until I told them “I have something to say & I’m going to say it...”
•••
This was disappointing to me, as I was one of the only youth, one of very few racialized women, & the only self-identified Indigenous woman… I hadn’t seen any of the other speakers at the forum interrupted the way I was.
•••
I saw all White panels on diversity & inclusion. A critical lens when discussing advances in women’s issues was missing. I think the forum was so powerful, & could not have been organized more efficiently, but I was sure to use my space to acknowledge what was not being said, what needed to be said, & how youth especially in the audience can be ensuring they do this too. I’m so, so thankful for the experience & I’m even more thankful for the people I’ve met & connected with.”

“I’m hyper-independent; I’m probably too honest; I travel a lot for work; I get cranky if I haven’t been with mountains in a while; I live with 5 to 9/10 chronic pain; I don’t fake orgasms; & I’m notoriously bad at replying to messages.

I mean if you’re still here, good luck.

I’m also bisexual, single, & I’ve been happy in monogamous, ethically non-monogamous, & friends with benefits relationships. I don’t have a preference, what works for “us” is a shared decision.”

Bears are out in Kananaskis Country early sooo… bring your bear spray & freshen up on your bear safety ‼️

“The hikers from Calgary were on the trail to Kent Ridge on Sunday (Feb. 12) when they came across the bear about 800 metres from treeline – leading to one of the earliest sightings of a grizzly bear in K-Country in recent memory… “We’re probably about a month away from when bears typically start to show up,” said John Paczkowski, human wildlife coexistence team lead with Alberta Parks.”

This really underscores ✨human responsibility✨ to know & practice bear safety. If you’re feeling really unsure or anxious, visit a tourist information booth or building and have a chat about recent bear sightings and safety based on the kind of bears in the area.

Bouldering is teaching me a lot about humility and has really given me an refreshed view on committed practice 😅

It’s been almost 1.5 months of bouldering. While I’ve been able to rely on my lower body strength and flexibility for top rope and lead rope climbing, I always avoided bouldering because I didn’t have the upper body strength to do it very well. You also have to learn in all the ugly ways in front of a busy gym of climbers waiting to get to the routes you’re occupying.

I’ve been seeking discomfort (not stress, got enough of that) in my life though, and once I realized I don’t have to coordinate my schedule with anyone to be able to go boulder I was sold. It’s given me something I’m not very good at to commit to, study, and practice.

This afternoon was shot in the purple leggings, and this morning’s sesh was in the orange shorts. My dumb ass forgot to take off my jewelry haha but I wanted to include the messy parts because that’s what makes me so excited about what I accomplished today. Trying to transition this into work.

This is period wear. Sexy, super absorbant period wear. I bleed once to three times a month; endometriosis, adenomyosis, chronic pelvic inflammatory disease, pelvic floor dysfunction, & congestive pelvic syndrome all contribute to my baseline 6/10 daily chronic pain, and my inconvenient reality of stress-induced bleeding.

Some of my consistent practices for managing pelvic pain are:

⚡️My @ovira device. TENS technology (electrotherapy) uses a small battoperated device that sends mild electrical currents to your muscles to help reduce pain. I put it on my pelvis area and alternate with my lower back.

🌱 Raspberry leaf tea. This plant medicine does incredible healing for your uterine lining.

🥗 A vegan diet. I’ll post more about this separately, but a vegan diet has been the most significant practice I’ve adopted to manage my pelvic pain. Since 2018 I’ve gone to tens of doctors and treatments, and none have had a more life changing impact than critically examining my relationship to food. 

🩲 Period underwear. This has more to do with comfort and reducing my waste and costs associated with bleeding, and damn have these underwear done what they set out to do. The line I’m wearing is by @knix, and clearly I’m into it.

I talk pretty openly about my journey with pelvic pain. I don’t usually feel sexy when I’m bleeding or having a pelvic flare, but I’m also someone who loves matching underwear and lingerie sets… sooo I had fun making it kinda sexy this time. Thanks for the gift @knix.

Grants for digital accessibility projects in Indigenous, Northern, and rural communities ‼️➡️ CIRA (Canadian Internet Registration Authority), the national non-profit that manages the .ca domain and more, is working to tackle the digital divide that leaves many remote communities, like where I grew up in Water Valley, and Northern and Indigenous communities, without equitable access to internet. The way they’re doing this: with over $1 million of grants annually and the Net Good program.

First, why the need for the grants? The digital divide in what is currently Canada disproportionately affects rural and Indigenous people:
​​ 
‼️ 5% of Canadian households have no residential internet connection.

‼️ 1/2 of rural and 1/3 of First Nation households have access to the “basic” speed target of 50 megabits per second (Mbps) download and 10 Mbps upload set by Canada’s communications regulator in 2016. 

‼️ Now more than ever, students need reliable access and safety on the internet. Internet access is a contributing factor to Indigenous graduation rates.

The digital divide in Canada can be the result of many factors, including systemic racism, high costs for technology and online access, differences in the availability of online connectivity resources, and lacking digital literacy. 

So, what is CIRA doing about it? Net Good by CIRA, is a program that seeks to support communities, projects and policies that make the internet better for communities across Canada. Under this program, over $1 million grant dollars are awarded to rural and Indigenous community leaders addressing the digital divide.

Check the link in my biography to learn more about accessing the CIRA Net Good programming! There a two links: one to the grant website, and one to the CIRA's Grants: What Applicants Need to Know information webinar recording.

#ciradotca #Sponsored #digitaldivide #digitalaccessibility @ciradotca

📸: @roseandrangephoto

I spent my best formative years in a trailer park in Water Valley, Alberta. But access to water, electricity, and food were inconsistent and unreliable under our circumstances - and so too was the internet. Even today, the rural community has spotty internet access. CIRA is working to tackle the digital divide that leaves many remote communities, like Water Valley, and Indigenous communities, without equitable access to internet. The way they’re doing this: with over $1 million of grants annually and the Net Good program.

Amplifying CIRA’s initiatives is aligned with my values derived from lived experience; from studying the digital divide intensively in my Communication Studies degree program at York University; and from being a mother and community member. If you are looking to address digital access and equity in your communities, I highly recommend exploring the Net Good program and CIRA grants. 

Check the link in my biography to learn more about accessing the CIRA Net Good programming! There a two links: one to the grant website, and one to the CIRA's Grants: What Applicants Need to Know information webinar recording.

#ciradotca #Sponsored #digitaldivide #digitalaccessibility @ciradotca 

📸: @roseandrangephoto

I love that I grew up on 90s country, I love that my mum’s old boots are +30 years worn, and I love that Water Valley was the best part of growing up.

“My best childhood years were in a trailer park in rural Alberta where boiling the water clean, trips to the food banks, driving 30min to the bus stop for a 1hr bus ride, stuffing our faces with wild raspberries before dinner, and spending entire days making intricate play structures in the bush were, in my young mind, normal things to do. The best things to do, actually. Perhaps in spite of being in a chronic, destitute financial state, my single mother (@solange.lalonde) of three daughters shaped our understanding of wealth and a ‘good life’ as being one that centres our relationship and access to nature.”

We go back to camp at the lower campgrounds and go to the Water Valley rodeo during the summer, but the liquor store/trailer where a baby moose got stuck in one year is for sale, and I really really want to buy it.

📸: @roseandrangephoto 

#WaterValley #90scountry #countrymusic

The Commonwealth Charter (2013) is a set of principles / values that all commonwealth countries committed to. This morning with over 4,200 registrants and a few panelists from around the world, I contributed to ‘A Decade of the Commonwealth Charter: Young Leaders’ Dialogue’ @commonwealthorg (London, UK) where we explored the Charter’s applicability, relevancy, and limitations from youth perspectives. It truly was the most dynamic, engaging, interactive, and honest panel I’ve experienced and I’m really proud of how we confronted living colonial legacies, White/Western saviourism, and accountability.

These are some clips of my contributions. You can access the full recording and my fellow panelists’ brilliance via the link in my bio.

On the Commonwealth Charter: “The Commonwealth Charter expresses the commitment of member states to the development of free and democratic societies and the promotion of peace and prosperity to improve the lives of all the people of the Commonwealth.” There are 16 principles and values. Google to learn more; the Canadian government has committed to the Charter as a commonwealth ‘nation.’

P.S. International Development Studies with streams in Policy and Governance and Indigenous Studies was one of my honours BA majors at @yorkuniversity; I cannot strain enough how much I rely on and appreciate the education I received in this program. People always laughed at the IDS kids like “good luck finding a job,” and I have to say that what I gained from the program, and studying abroad internationally several times with the university, contributes to some of my most desirably employable skills. 

#commonwealth #commonwealthcharter #commonwealthgames

It’s graduation day, 2018. I was going up to the stage with Zyra on my hip; she had been in two full years of university classes and deserved to be on it. Ruth, family and mentor, saw me getting stopped by a few White women citing non-existing policies against having a baby on the stage. Ruth came to shield me from them, and Zy and I proceeded to graduate Summa Cum Laude (Highest Academic Honours).

Ruth taught me how to navigate academia and policy work with resilience and self/collective advocacy. She was there every time the institution attempted to smother my light with racism and discrimination. In many ways, Ruth played a pivotal role in guiding my journey that’s remained true to heart work, community work, disruption work.

Zy and I graduated with the chancellor, who would a few years later be honoured at the same Alumni Awards (and gave a shoutout in his speech that of the tens of thousands of students he graduated, Zy’s was the littlest hand he shook). On that November evening I had the incredible gift of being with Ruth and their fiancé, Blu. It was a very full, continuing circle moment. 

I am reminded how fortunate I am for love like this, and these pictures have done the best job at capturing it. 

Also, @beautyandthetreatz love you bes fren. We’ve been through ittttt and you’ve always been there.

A bio for new buddies & folks who post me (everything you need is in my profile link too, so represent me accurately please 😘)!

“Larissa Crawford proudly passes on Métis & Jamaican ancestry to her daughter, Zyra, & is a 28 year-old published Indigenous, anti-racism, & climate justice researcher, policy advisor, & restorative circle keeper with over 14 years of experience.

After graduating from York University in 2018 with a Double Major Honours B.A. in Communications & International Development Studies- Summa Cum Laude & a toddler on her hip- Larissa became disabled at 23 years old.

While navigating these new realities, Larissa worked with the Government of Ontario as an Indigenous Policy Advisor with the Ministry of Energy; as an Advisor at the Ontario Anti-Racism Directorate, Ministry of the Solicitor General; as a community mediator and restorative circle keeper; & more.

These experiences contributed to & informed Larissa’s expertise in energy policy, public policy, anti-racism policy, accessibility practices, race-based data collection, restorative practice and conflict resolution, & decolonization & Indigenization in the workplace.

Also contributing to her expertise, Larissa carries lived experiences as an Indigenous & Black woman; a survivor of sexual violence & poverty; a person living with chronic pain disabilities & brain damage; having lived in both rural & urban settings; & as a young mother.

In 2019, Larissa reached a point where racism, ableism, & ageism in her workplaces were having real & serious impacts on her well-being. Consequently, Larissa quit her last job & gave herself 4 months to start her business.

Future Ancestors Services is an Indigenous & Black-owned, youth-led professional services social enterprise that advances climate justice & systemic barrier removal with lenses of anti-racism and ancestral accountability. Through an intergenerational, disabled, & queer team of professionals & advisors, they provide services to +400 diverse clients. They do this while centering decolonized & Indigenized practices, & are constantly reimagining how we can learn, relate, & work together in healthy ways.”

The @cdnroots Annual Gathering was such a gift 🏔️♥️ An incredible youth committee led the organization of a gathering at @banffcentre that brought over 150 Indigenous youth from coast to coast to coast across what is currently Canada.

Some of my highlights from our week nestled among the mountains:

✅ There was sooo much land-based learning. Everyday, it was a natural part of the program, much of which was facilitated by Carolynne Crawley (Mi’kmaw, Black, Irish from Nova Scotia, based in Toronto) and Daryl Kootenay (Stoney Nakoda Nation and Dine based in Alberta). Carolynne is a Forest Therapy Guide that led time on the land that was spiritual, somatic, and grounding; @hihawagichi led tours in the area and shared the histories and sacredness of sites that have been scrubbed clean with colonial innocence (🙃).

✅ Having the space and time to really get to know people from across what is currently Canada, and from very remote places in many cases. The Gathering was fully funded for all participants, which made this all possible.

✅ Climbing and bouldering at the @banffcentre with gathering buddies!!! What a great facility, the instructors/staff are sooo kind and helpful.

✅ I’ve worked with @cdnroots across several contracts, and my love for the people behind the scenes has grown deeply. The team was so humbly involved in every aspect of the gathering program and beyond. Their endurance, presence, and effectiveness was aspirational.

✅ Sharing the space with my mum and Zyra. This was Zy’s first conference where she was requested as a guest speaker by name 🥹 she’s been coming to conferences with me, and with me and my mum, since she was less than a month old. She thrives in spaces like this and I’m doing everything I can to ensure she always know that she belongs.

The liquor store / trailer in Water Valley is for sale, and I remember growing up one year a baby moose got stuck in it. I really really want to buy it and call it Biibii d’aariyaanl (baby moose).

Pictured here in front of the saloon where we’d get fries on Fridays and my mum would get rowdy during rodeo season lol.

📷: @roseandrangephoto

That lil nose. I wanted a nose job my whole life, and it wasn’t coming from a place of bodily autonomy and empowerment; it came from a place of deep insecurity with my natural misalignments with Eurocentric beauty standards.

And then, when I was 21 years old, I saw that lil nose in Zyra’s 3D ultrasound.

“That’s MY nose. How could I explain to her that I had changed OUR nose because I didn’t think it was beautiful? How could I let someone else’s beauty standards colonize yet another gift from our ancestors? She is deserving of more. I am deserving of more.”

I know that had I gotten a nose job, it would be for reasons I wouldn’t be proud of as a living and future ancestor. This quote from Nicki Ferland in the @themamawiproject captures the sentiments I had when I saw her nose, prompting a more conscious personal practice and profound (and at times, uncomfortable) journey of self and ancestral love.

“Ancestral accountability means to speak and behave in a way that respects and honours your ancestors. When we leave this world, we will stand before them in the next, and explain our decisions and our actions.

Our decisions and actions today also create the world of tomorrow for those we will one day be the ancestors of. We will also have to explain ourselves to them. That knowledge guides my choices.”

I took this picture this evening and it made me think of my recent speech where I talked about this ultrasound and ancestral accountability. Ahh I love her so much.

I’m so thankful that upcoming generations are witnessing and experiencing more visible and celebrated Blackness in Indigenous spaces.

I didn’t meet a self-identifying Black Indigenous person until my later years in university. I took part in a digital storytelling research project as a subject alongside several others, and it was during these 5 intensive days that I grew to appreciate just how much we’ve been denied - especially by our own communities.

I see anti-Black racism play out in Indigenous spaces and minds frequently, and I’ve been asked several times to facilitate conversations about this harm between parties.

I don’t post or share much about that side of my work, but some of the most consistent veins of anti-Black racism I see in these spaces are:

🪶 Excluding Black and darker skinned Indigenous peoples from visual media claiming “Indigenous diversity”

🪶 White Indigenous people editing their skin tone to look considerably darker when convenient or aesthetically appealing

🪶 Exploitative appropriation of Black hairstyles, makeup, music, and culture without recognition, without inclusion of Black Indigenous people, and without any spirit of solidarity or reciprocity 

🪶 Disproportionate questioning of ancestry and connection to community for people who do not present as White Indigenous (blood quantum politics)

🪶 Use of the N word, whether colloquially or violently with the hard “r”

I’m thankful for people like @blanco_710 and @jurneebygrace for taking up and holding space to be unapologetically Black and equally unapologetically Indigenous. @healing7gens embraced us like I haven’t really seen before.

(When I present on Indigeneity - and not specifically about First Nations, Métis, and Inuit - I take a moment to acknowledge that when I say “Indigenous” I’m referring to a global context. Blackness is inherently Indigenous; many of our ancestors were Indigenous people stolen in the Trans Atlantic Slave Trade and brought to stolen Indigenous lands. I’ve found this to be a mediative approach to addressing some of the underlying assumptions driving the harm listed above (check out the work of George Sefa Dei for more).)

(1/2) I’ve been public speaking since I was 16. I did my first TEDx when I was 17 about the library I started at a girl’s academy in Ghana. I won every student council election through speeches and school engagement. At 23 I did another TEDx about surviving the racism and ableism in the workplace, which is on the TED website. I’ve had Zyra on stage since she was a few weeks old.

I often get told I have a “gift”, that I’m such a “natural” on stage. But the other day an audience member came up to me and said, “I don’t want to call what you just did a ‘gift’ because I think you’ve worked very hard to be able to do what you do. Every person in the room was listening to you.” I felt so seen.

I wanted to dump some insights for how I approach public speaking so when I get the question about “what are your tips for speaking?” I can send them the links to this post and the next lol.

🎤 I flirt with the audience, especially if it’s a challenging topic. For example, at one keynote I opened it with “Ok see this pylon orange dress I have on, fashion psychology research tells me that if I’m wearing a bright colour you’ll receive the tough things I have to say with a more joyful tone, so here we are 😉.”

🎤 I avoid having any physical barrier between the me and the audience. This can psychologically affect how the audience receives the message.

🎤 I use the whole stage if I’m able to physically to do so. Either way, I try to look at all directions of the space for audience members to feel seen and engaged.

🎤 This might be just how my brain works: when I look at the audience, I don’t actually look to see them, I’m looking inward. I see what I’m about to say.

🎤 I always request a hand held microphone. Lapel mics are not made with women’s clothing in mind, and over-ear mics typically only come in White-skin colour. 

I hope this is useful to someone ♥️ More tips in the next post.

📸: @wpgchamber, Mike Sudoma

(2/2) Continuing on my approach to public speaking:

🎤 I don’t make a speech usually until the night before. If I try to prepare them too long in advance, I get mixed up with what speech is what. The other insights below are why this approach works for me.

🎤 I only speak on topics I’m able to see reflected in my own lived experiences, knowledge, and identities. I don’t speak on behalf of anyone. One way I stay true to that is by incorporating lines like “In my experience,” “What I witnessed was,” “I’m not here to speak on behalf of anyone, everything I speak to is informed by my own understanding of what I’ve heard and witnessed in my communities” and…

🎤 If you don’t know something, say you don’t know it! Humility and honesty builds trust with the audience. I’ll typically say “Well the best way I can answer that now is…”, “I actually don’t know. But send me an email with your question and I’ll follow up with you following more reflection and research.”

🎤 When given the chance, I try to go to the whole conference and event. Especially multiple-day ones. This time helps me engage with the audience members before a speech, which always informs what kind of personal story telling and case studies I’ll weave throughout the speech. I’m always especially drawn to what the youth have to say.

🎤 I determine that level of vulnerability I have the capacity to offer the audience.

🎤 I invest a lot of time and energy into critical self-reflection, which I’d say is the biggest proponent of my effectiveness as a speaker. Understanding my values; thinking about what enabled the harm I experienced in workplaces; how my worldview shapes my truths; all of these exploratory topics and more reveal public speaking gold. It’s the truth in humanity, in making mistakes, in overcoming adversity, in not overcoming diversity, that I am frequently told is how I connect with people.

🎤 I laugh, I acknowledge what’s happening around me (often Zy is pulling at me, putting dandelions in my hair, sitting on my feet) and keep on going. “Perfection” isn’t something I’ve ever worked towards as a public speaker, because frankly I find it boring.

📸: @wpgchamber, Mike Sudoma

10/10 acute pain. I’ve been in the hospital since Tuesday in Calgary (sent home without further treatment) and then Toronto (they were trying to do the same). Haven’t been able to walk, drink, eat for over a week. Pain hitting a constant state of 10/10 since Wednesday morning.

But the doctors and their residents don’t believe that when it’s coming from a Black woman. A young Black woman (the statistics and research support my lived experience). And someone who has chronic pain disabilities? Ya right. “We don’t give pain meds to people with chronic pain,” were initial, actual words out of a doctor’s mouth.

I’m pissed and so are the nurses witnessing how I’m being treated and dismissed. I fucking hate having to actively advocate for myself when I’m at the pain level of unmedicated vaginal childbirth.

I don’t have energy for much else in this caption. This is real time and I’m trying to process everything. I just needed to get this anger outside my mind and body.

One thing I am holding onto is that despite all of this, I was able to prerecord my contributions to #congressh (why I’m in Toronto). My voice was weak and barely audible, didn’t sleep, and high off morphine, but I did it from my hospital bed. I’m resilient af and no doctor will tell me otherwise.

#thisisnotahighlightreel

I’ve never wanted to not be in pain more. I’m so beat down by my body and the healthcare system. I suck right now too. I’ve been a shit and absent manager. I can’t even carry Zy up a stair. I haven’t been talking to anyone, and if I do they wish I didn’t.

If there’s anything chronic pain does to me - apart from the obvious - it’s that it makes me feel very hard to love. And I say that with profound self-awareness. I’m conscious of my tone and behaviour, but I don’t have the capacity to be any more than I am in that moment - especially for the sake of someone else’s feelings.

I’m not seeking kind words, this is just a shitty part of chronic pain that I don’t see people talking about enough. 

#chronicpainisaparty #thisisnotahighlightreel

I took this picture as the sun burned this ominous red/pink hue through the smoke, and at first I felt sad seeing it contrasted on Zy’s lil face.

And then I noticed her puffer, and it felt infuriating. She had two summers without blanketing wildfire smoke smothering her tiny lungs. She will have life long climate-induced breathing issues.

What is currently Canada was (and is) in a standstill waiting to see what communities will be most directly targeted with wildfires next, and how it will affect our most vulnerable.

Zy and I are incredibly privileged. But communities like @rsupernault’s were burned to the ground. Disproportionately rural and Indigenous people, and our non human kin, have had their entire lives, histories, futures, health upended.

And yet, people in Canada saw very little global news coverage or outcry- especially from US-based “global news” outlets and American activists.

‼️ The news that is being covered centres how Americans are experiencing byproducts of the apocalyptic reality in the North - not the fires themselves, or how they've affected Canadians. ‼️

It's a cultural phenomenon I have to deal with regularly when working south of the border. "You can't call this global if you're only centring American voices, language, experiences, activists, lives," is something I have to say WAY too often to clients.

American cultural hegemony (this is an example) is a detriment to everyone, especially the global climate movement.

👉🏽 Please start/keep seeing and calling this out when Americans do this.

👉🏽 Circulate media that responsibly covers what’s happening in what is currently Canada.

👉🏽 Support our communities with resources requested. Visit @rsupernault’s page for more on how to support East Prairie Métis Settlement.

👉🏽 VOTE FOR POLITICAL LEADERS THAT ACKNOWLEDGE THE CAUSE AND IMPACTS OF THESE WILDFIRES. Alberta (mostly Northern and rural Alberta) just voted in a woman who is calling these wildfires ‘arson’. Ontario voted in a man who has actively defunded firefighting resources and services.

- Sincerely, a pissed off mum. #zyranova

This is the unscripted moment I very directly named the harm a White woman caused a group of Indigenous youth at the conference I was speaking at. My mum voice had the ballroom absolutely silent lol.

When I talk about incidents of harm for educational purposes, I don’t target the individual; I speak to the behaviours and assumptions they acted on, the context (policy, institutional, cultural, historical) that made it possible, and the impact of their actions. Anyone anywhere under the same circumstances, acting on the same assumptions, could cause that harm. Very rarely is it ever a truly individual incident.

Bringing the harm up to a systemic level holds more space to address the root causes of the harm, and to identify practices that can be built and implemented to mitigate that harm in the future. 

“I don’t even remember what you look like, but I hope you’re here, and that when we think about relationships to time, and our own cultural relationships to time, that we’re also aware of the harm we may cause in imposing that on other cultural experiences of time.”

Credit: Pembina Institute Renewable Energy in Remote Communities conference, Whitehorse, Yukon, 2022

#IndigenousPeoplesDay (June 21st) Indigenizing isn’t just about our work or activity outputs - that mural, that campaign, that video - it’s also about the ways we work and relate to one another, in how we create and who we include in that process.

I stopped apologizing for having Zyra on stage, in class, in the office, or on a zoom call a long time ago - she’s here, and you’re welcome. This is what Indigenizing can look like. When you come from a cultural worldview that places value on the wisdom children carry, you can see their presence for the gift that it truly is. 

I was 21 and pregnant, starting my fourth of five years of university. I knew I’d continue in school, just like my mum did with three kids. At the beginning of the semester I booked a meeting with each professor to say, “I will be bringing my baby to class, and this is what I need to access my education and be respected as a young mother - how can I respect you and your classroom while honouring my needs?” And at 12 days old, Zyra was in class, and she began a university career of A+ class presentations while breatfeeding. 

Working in Indigenous and Black spaces set a standard for me; they taught me not to apologize for having her there. They taught me to see the lessons in all the struggle that came with having her there. They taught me to see the Indigenous resilience that at so many times was questioned, challenged, and delegitimized.

This Indigenous Peoples Day (tomorrow) and beyond consider how you’re holding caregiver friendly space: what can you do to signal that children are welcome? Kids can’t always be there, but then what can you do to support caregivers in navigating that barrier?

Zyra teaches me and anyone she briefs with her presence how to see that holding space for Indigenization truly benefits everyone, human and non-human. We have the future we’re working towards in our presence, and we can learn so much from that.

Opening and closing video footage by @cdnroots x Cass Gardiner

#IndigenousPeoplesDay #parenting #parentinghacks #indigenousparenting #blackparenting #education #decolonization #indigenization #afroindigenous #entrepreneur #businesstips #zyranova

#NationalIndigenousPeoplesDay I include Blackness in my understanding of Indigeneity. So many of us in what is currently North America are descendants of Indigenous peoples stolen from their Indigenous lands. Our Indigenous memories have in many ways been denied, but our DNA connects us to a complex universe of Indigenous strength, histories, and futures that reach far beyond the Trans Atlantic Slave Trade.

If I’m speaking exclusively to Métis, First Nations, and Inuit in what is currently Canada, I’m very specific in my language. Otherwise, when I use the word ‘Indigenous’ I’m speaking in a global context - and yes, I include Black diasporas.

Anti-Black racism in Indigenous spaces - denying someone’s Indigeneity because of their Blackness - is unacceptable. I do my work, primarily behind the scenes, in facilitating our communities’ channels of communication, understanding, and ultimately solidarity. It’s in those moments that I have the most hope for our futures.

To build your own understanding of Indigeneity and Blackness, please refer to the work of George Sefa Dei (University of Toronto). He’s supported me for yearsssss in the language I’ve needed to build solidarity between and within Indigenous communities, and I’m incredibly grateful for the wisdom this Elder carries.

📷: @mecohbain

#afroindigenous

Invalidating the pain and barriers someone experiences because you see them out cosplaying able-bodiness for a sec isn’t a cute look (but my favourite blue bikini is).

In all of these pictures of life lately I’m dealing with 7-9/10 pain. Disabilities (+ a wee MCL tear) and they’re symptoms (fatigue has been brutal lately) can look fit, desperate, self-indulgent, introverted, extroverted, a mess - and yes, often times invisible. And obviously so much more.

Part of unpacking ableism in our own minds and spaces is acknowledging that disabilities don’t always look the way we assume they should. In my opinion, 1) asking people informally or formally what they need to access a space/relationship in a healthy way, and 2) having more gentleness for yourself and your need for rest and pleasure - whether you have disabilities or not - are great ways to build your skills in having respectful relationships with people who have disabilities and frankly, anyone. 🫂 

#chronicpainisaparty #melaninandbabyoil

A lil demisexual bisexual existing fluidly under umbrellas of monogamy and non-monogamy, preference matching the connections and circumstances 🏳️‍🌈 I’ve never denied that I’ve existed like this most my life, but I’ve let y’all in on the fun this past year more than I ever have so openly, with more accurate language.

Not sure about the words I’m using? Google it - or better yet, read a book 📚 Swipe for 4 great intro books on non-monogamy, sexuality, psychology, and history (I put them in my personal recommended order). I’ll do brief book reports on here eventually.

#CanadaDay 5 Settler Moves Towards Innocence. Azeezah Kanji, you are so special. Instead of saying happy Canada Day, I wanted to share this @yellowheadinstitute brief I came across a few months ago. I’ve used it a lot in my personal and professional vocabulary.

Kanji masterfully weaves Indigenous experiences across Canada, Palestine, and India to illustrate a very usable glossary. Here, I’ve shared some of my most used terms from the brief and some examples I’ve added to expand on their relevance in our day to day lives.

I don’t celebrate Canada Day, and I don’t stand for O’Canada. Instead of shutting someone down when they express their resistance to patriotism, consider “Patriotism in whose interest?” Before yelling “People died for this country! Stand up!” consider everyone you could actually be referring to in that sentiment.

#canada #canadaday2023 #decolonization #reconciliation #afroindigenous

Touchdown in Kigali, Rwanda for the 2023 @women_deliver summit 🇷🇼 I wanted to spend the first few days deepening my appreciation for this beautiful country.

✳️ It was incredibly smooth getting here, and from the start conference goers felt welcomed. It’s feels like the whole city has invested in this event, from billboards to hotels (all fully booked) to shuttles. I have never witnessed a city more competently  execute an international gathering.

✳️ With over 609 registrants for the Gender and Climate Justice Pre-Conference, I’m very lucky to have gotten in hah. It was a great space to start @women_deliver with, and I truly felt so inspired by the Elder activists that took the stage. In my first direct exposure to Rwandan culture, I was left in awe.

✳️ I needed to get outside and do some land-based learning. A 1 hour guided 4X4 excursion at @fazenda_sengha. It cost $5 each way between downtown and Fazenda (~25 minutes), and $45 for the excursion. I ended the sesh with a $2 Moringa tea, and a whole appreciation for the staff and their beautiful home. I learned so much from the tour about how locals live, wildlife, and environment. I’m in love.

#WD2023 #TravelRwanda

Representation my 14 year old self so desperately needed. Never have I seen Black hair so celebrated and unapologetically adorned than I have at @women_deliver in Kigali.

I laughed, cried, and learned from the women who privileged me with their time and image to make this video. From every corner of this Earth, these women carry their ancestral gifts with pride; in this space, Eurocentric beauty standards seem to be the minority, and I can’t say I’ve experienced that often in professional spaces.

I grew up being relentlessly bullied for my hair, no matter how I wore it. Boys would throw things in my afro from the back of the class to see what would stick. Boyfriends would say they didn’t like my braids and wanted me to wear weaves, teaching me I was only desirable with straight or loose curly hair. I fried my hair with relaxers for most of my teens. I spoke with many of the women in this video about navigating the racism and discrimination targeting our hair - socially, culturally, and LEGALLY. Around the world, Black hair is denounced, controlled, and demonized.

We also spoke about our healing journeys, and our ongoing efforts in reconciling our relationship to our ancestors and self through our hair. For many of us, how we choose to style our hair now comes from a place of personal autonomy and empowerment, rather than desperate efforts to align ourselves with Whiteness.

Walking around the conference centre halls trying to figure out how and what I wanted to cover from this @women_deliver space as a ‘Media Influencer’, I had taken a moment to appreciate the beautiful hairstyles. I thought “Damn, if only I could have witnessed this as a child.” And while there can only be so many of us here, I finally thought that capturing this experience of representation was one way I could bring the incredible impact of @women_deliver to you.

Black hair is beautiful.
Black hair is professional.
Black hair is regal.
Black hair is desirable.

And just like that, we’ve wrapped up the world’s largest gathering for gender equality with words from @michelleobama. Conferences will bring me in to cover or speak in their spaces knowing I have a track record of calling shit out when I need to.

Whenever asked how my time here is going, I couldn’t help but say “It’s so nice to not need to need to be a disrupter here; the was planned, executed, and attended by disrupters across generations. This really was a space to learn and connect in healthy ways.” 

Why I was so impressed, and what others can learn from @women_deliver:

✅ Local and Indigenous people were at the forefront of every part of this conference. Staff, performers, journalists, speakers, volunteers - we all left with a deep understanding of these people’s resilience, joy, master organizational skills, and beauty. Land acknowledgements were done soooo effectively, and were always followed by an act of local welcoming to us guests.

✅ Gender neutral bathrooms were everywhere. Gendered bathrooms were converted with makeshift signage, which was a great way to adapt to the physical space.

✅ Wellness and Quiet, as well as chest feeding spaces were easily found across the conference centre.

✅ This was the most accessible space I’ve seen at a large conference. Signage clearly pointed to the most direct and accessible routes to any part of the conference centre. Braille and QR codes for audio bites were found at many of the booths. All sessions in the main plenary and ceremonies had international sign language interpretation. You could access captions and translation for sessions directly in the conference app.

✅ Youth were directly involved in planning the conference, and it showed. We weren’t stuck away in an obscure corner, and conference goers were constantly encouraged to go to the youth zone - and they did! Bean bags, pillows, couches, and food and beverages made the space incredibly welcoming to all ages.

There is so much more, but those were a few reasons why I loved this conference so much. #WD2023 #TravelRwanda

If there’s anything I learned from 3 years of brain bleed recovery, it’s to listen to the physio 🙂 The hardest physio direction I get is “rest.” I’d push through with my brain bleed and I’d be incapacitated from work, family, volunteering for months; I know my toxic relationship to productivity elongated my healing to a point where acquired brain damage still affects me (especially reading aloud and typing).

With this tiny MCL tear and superior tibiofibular joint sprain that happened in June (following, on the same knee, a hyperextension injury in May), I’ve really done my best to apply what I learned from my brain bleed. I’ve doing the lil exercises, I’ve taken off over 3 weeks of gym time, and am slowly coming back this week.

The role my functional strength training and bouldering/climbing plays daily in maintaining balanced mental and emotional health makes it the most difficult to “rest.” It can be completely destabilizing. With a Spring season that was particularly defined by traumatic events, I was reallllly relying on my time in the gyms for a sense of peace. 

I do appreciate the time off, it’s the longest I’ve taken since starting bouldering this January. My knee is feeling better, and my physios and doctors are happy. I also had to find solace by finding my way back to other activities that bring me peace, like only yoga sessions, swimming, art, and lots of playground time with Zyra.

Here are a few moments where I’m stumbling through this healing process.

“I feel like a guest judge on drag race!” Following my morning keynote, a diverse group of youth grades 8 to newly graduated prepped social impact projects that address anti-Black racism in our community. Then following a keynote from @kingofbayst, they pitched their ideas to us as judges and we provided feedback.

Some of my feedback to groups:

🎤 “Take a few steps into the light y’all, you deserve to be seen!”

🎤 “I really appreciated how, when you saw a team member struggling in their presentation, you intervened as an opportunity to help while creating a moment of humanity.”

🎤 “Your steady eye contact demonstrated how present you were, and made me feel more accountable to you as a presenter.”

🎤 “Explain the process - let us know what actually needs to happen to get from point A to point B.”

I learned a lot from @kingofbayst in such a short amount of time. Most strikingly, Wes was able to speak to systemic barriers AND our agency for hard work and the consequences of our choices.

Thank you @saralaustin @children1stca for involving me in this event. It was so grounding, and I feel so grateful to have spent an afternoon with these rising stars in Calgary.

Finding and fostering reciprocal mentorship relationships 🎤 When I was in an Indigenous women’s circle while at @yorkuniversity, we talked about asking what we can give, not what we can take, when approaching other Indigenous women with extractive requests. This forever shaped my approach to relationships, especially in the context of mentorship.

In this clip I share how I’ve found, and then cultivated, a life changing reciprocal mentorship relationship with Dr. Lorne Foster. From his reputation as one of Canada’s leading legacy anti-racism researchers and policy creators, to his Black Panther Party influenced roots -  Dr. Foster showed me what it means to be a community member, leader, man, husband, activist in all the healthiest ways.

When people enter a mentoring relationship and all are regarded as mentees and mentors, and it is understood that everyone has something to learn from everyone, we can call this a reciprocal mentorship relationship. Reciprocal mentorship is reflected in Indigenous knowledge systems around the world, because it necessitates a worldview that holds diverse experiences and ways of knowing as valuable sources of wisdom and guidance (e.g. our children have as much to teach us as we do them, people with autism are sacred, Elders and their knowledge must be honoured).

But, only intention doesn’t make a reciprocal relationship; other factors that can hamper or promote reciprocity in mentorship include cultural safety, power dynamics, societal privileges, etc., and this is why having access to mentors that embody our identities and experiences Is SO important. Some of the most invaluable guidance I received from Dr. Foster was about creating and navigating disruptive anti-racism work in White and Western institutions as a *Black* person. A White mentor is neither qualified nor best situated to support me in that way.

When asked for mentoring support, I know I struggle to keep up with the quantity and scope of the requests. But I know I struggled more before the mentors who invested in me despite the quantity and scope of requests they received. So, I try my best to honour these gifts. How I do that can be another post, eventually 👋🏽

“A study resource. Get into this. The website and information is brilliant. So necessary for us all to understand the ways this culture functions and our alignment with it. How we are all harmed by it in different ways. We uphold this. The “sense of urgency” is one that I go back to often as I examine our “Rest is Resistance”framework. 

“Applying the urgency of racial and social justice to our every day lives in ways that perpetuate power imbalance and disregard for our need to breathe and pause and reflect.”

Link is in bio for this extensive website under: “White Supremacy Culture Characteristics.” It will take slow study to deepen into the principles. Take your time. Turning off comments because you haven’t done the homework of actually spending time in the website and reading and journaling and resting in between to be pontificating yet. Go slow. Get off SOCIAL MEDIA platforms typing so much in these threads. We Will Rest!” – @thenapministry 

When I’m doing relationship to time work and/or White Fragility, this culture is what I always cover in “How we see the living legacies of this racist history today:” The more we know about our histories, and the more we know about how they’ve shaped our realities today, the better equipped we are to dismantle the root causes of our contemporary pain, suffering, and discrimination.

@thenapministry is an incredible space and resource. Link to the full resource in their bio.

I acknowledge that my delays in communication this Spring and Summer seasons have been inconvenient for many in my network, and I take this very seriously. This is not a reflection of the importance I place on our work and connections.

My 2023 Spring season was characterized by a series of deeply traumatic events. Parting ways with one of our Founding Directors in late March, after over a year of restorative efforts, was quickly followed by several incidents of sexual assaults while fulfilling contracts. I was subsequently hospitalized for severe complications with my disabilities in late May through June, where medical malpractice and further sexual assault took place. 

For generations, our ancestors were denied rest and healing. I am in a constant state of exploring what it looks like to honour what was stolen from them through my personal and professional practice.

After a few months moving through this pain with rest and connection in my personal life, I am able to articulate to you and myself why I have been severely incapacitated in my work. I am now able to better come back to my work with the presence and energy you deserve.

Throughout the month of August I am following up with emails and requests starting from May 2023. Thank you in advance for your patience and compassion as we create a reality where healing is aligned with how we understand ‘productivity’.

(@ancestorsfuture will be going through a fundamental shift with more leadership from our incredible and growing team. Taking the rest I have a right to - but have privilege in actually realizing - has helped me get back to a place where I can serve y’all with the version of myself that y’all deserve.)

It’s #GlobalClimbingDay! I found climbing in the most difficult times of my brain bleed recovery, when @colourthetrails was offering an introduction to indoor climbing course, and then an 8-week course.

I fell in love with the sport when I got to climb with mountains through a 2-day outdoor course offered by @thecrushcollective, and then a progression course by @soul.of.miistaki . I’ve taken several more courses over the years with them.

I grew up on climbing mats with my mum and dad, my dad doing advanced mountain and ice climbing when he was in the army. As I grew older I was able to climb at camps and birthday parties, but I never did sustainably because my single mother of three girls just couldn’t afford it. I held onto my aspirational love for the sport though, with rock climbing being #57 on my grade 9 bucket list.

Organizations like @colourthetrails, @soul.of.miistaki, @thecrushcollective,  @multiculturaltrailnetwork, and @bipocoutdoorgearlibrary are incredibly committed to making sports like climbing accessible, which from my experience has looked like:

🧗🏽‍♀️ Offering courses, excursions, and rentals at no, low, or sliding scale cost

🧗🏽‍♀️ Fostering learning spaces FOR Black, Indigenous, and racialized people in systemically White dominated sports

🧗🏽‍♀️ Coordinating rides to and from locations

🧗🏽‍♀️ Clearly signalling that all body types are welcome through communications and availability of diverse sizes of rentals

🧗🏽‍♀️ Enthusiastically holding caregiver friendly space whenever possible

🧗🏽‍♀️ Having continuous dialogue about what safety looks like to participants, volunteers, and instructors

🧗🏽‍♀️ Genuinely inquiring about how our disabilities and neurodiversity informs how we come to the space, and what we need from everyone to engage safely and comfortably

Climbing has brought me physical, mental, and emotional healing in ways no other practice or sport has been able to do. 

I have an overwhelming appreciation for what these organizations do, and I recommend following and supporting them as they continue to broaden their programming. 

📸 @allisonseto at my first @colourthetrails event in November 2021

“Laws passed by settler governments outlawed Indigenous cultural burns, and more than 100 years of fire suppression created “a volatile tinder box of forest fuels across the province” — according to a 2022 report published by the University of Victoria’s Environmental Law Centre — a tinderbox that is becoming increasingly flammable with global heating. 

Black, Indigenous and People of Colour are disproportionately impacted by catastrophic wildfires. In contrast with non-Indigenous communities, Indigenous ones are 18 times more likely to be evacuated from emergencies, including wildfires and floods. We are seeing that play out in the Northwest Territories and Okanagan fire complexes. 

“72 per cent of visible minorities in Canada live in areas that get overheated” giving them a higher chance of megafires, according to The Narwhal.

As well, while air pollution remains “very high risk” in the Okanagan, many migrant farm workers are expected or forced to continue work.

Megafires are a product of colonialism, from fossil fuel extraction and old growth logging on Indigenous lands, to the criminalization of Indigenous land stewardship. 

Read more in a recent feature I wrote for I𝔫𝔡𝔦𝔤𝔦𝔑𝔢𝔴$.

I was actually supposed to make this post about Calgary-based @wholisticbyAOR supplements back in March 2023. Over the years I’ve been approached by 11 supplement brands with requests for polished pictures beside their bottles. And of course, their aggressive timelines left me about a week to trial the product and create the content.

So, I’ve said no to all of them. 

I’m sharing about @wholisticbyAOR now because they gave me the space I needed to experience the product for myself over six months. I’ve been using:

💊MELATONIN + GABA: a powerful natural sleep-aid that helps reduce the time it takes to fall asleep, reset the body’s sleep-wake cycle, and promote temporary relaxation.

I’m careful with sleep aids, like melatonin, because I’ve been too reliant on them in the past. I’ve saved the Melatonin + GABA supplement for jet-lag while travelling across Canada and internationally the past a half year. This formula was incredibly effective, and didn’t give me the ‘groggy’ effect melatonin usually does when I wake up. On-the-go sleep regime staple.

💊MAGNESIUM CITRATE: helps to maintain muscle functions, and the body’s ability to metabolize nutrients.

Magnesium citrate was part of my regular supplement regime before trying WHOLISTIC. I’m sticking with them because they’re vegan, non-GMO, locally-based, and affordable - all WHOLISTIC supplements are $14-$26 a bottle. 

I take paid partnerships very seriously, and I turn them down if I don’t think I can represent the product or campaign authentically, or from my own experience. Thank you for allowing me to take the time I needed to build trust in your brand and product, @wholisticbyAOR. 

(Link in my bio to check them out 📲)

POV: you do your own braids

My non-Black mum taught herself how to do box braids when I was in middle school, and then taught me (parenting done right ehhh).

But I lived in Lethbridge, Southern Alberta… So core memories associated with having my hair in braids:

🖕🏽Having multiple partners tell me they didn’t like my braids because they made me look “too Black, I like your hair straight (weaves) more”

🖕🏽Everyone constantly asking me if my hair is real (one time my mum said ‘What about that shit dye job lady? Is that real?’ lmaooo)

🖕🏽White people constantly touching my braids without asking

🖕🏽Having my Indigeneity negated because again, I look “too Black” (and almost exclusively by White people)

It wasn’t until I travelled and lived around the world, exposing myself to a plethora of beauty standards and proud Black hairstyles, that I started to become conscious of how internalized anti-Black racism was in my mind and heart. I had to - and have to continue to - work SO hard to unpack that anti-Black racism. But it’s SO worth it, and I feel closer to my ancestors every time I let myself love their gifts.

I love my Afro and natural hair, and I feel most myself using this protective style. I’m at 1.5 days for this size and length of knotless braid, and I do a full rebraid every 2 months and top rows touchups in the time between. 

🐚 Jewelry from a street vendor in Kigali, Rwanada

From 2020 to IRL with @rbearhat 🎨 I’ve worked with Richelle for years, through all different clients, because she is a driving force of Calgary’s arts scene resistantly maturing social and ethical consciousness. And National accessArts Centre has been one channel through which she changes lives *every* *single* *day*. @accessartsca serves disabled artists and community members at the highest standards, and today I came to really appreciate that!

I facilitated a program opening dialogue for ~15 artists and we spent time exploring ancestry, rest, and respect. Our intention was to plant seeds of trust and vulnerability between the program artists, and to  gather an understanding of what a safe and respectful space looks like for them. With this, I’m creating a visual community agreement and facilitator guidelines (for the program facilitators). We’ll be together again at the end of the program to debrief ♥️

There was so much love in the time I got to share with this special group of people - I’m thankful for today.

Reasons why the @odihiempowers @biggerideasconference really got it right👇🏽

⭐️ Audience and speaker outreach was very relationship-oriented (watch @jujumil explain this and her role in 4th slide).

⭐️ Geographic setting was close to a major subway station, and a shuttle was organized to bring participants from the station to the venue. This made it very accessible to people using transit.

⭐️ The space was very intentionally intergenerational. You had speakers and audience members at very diverse places in their career and advocacy journeys, and this truly benefitted everyone there. I find this is a quality that is missing from most conferences I attend; they’re typically overwhelmingly youth or older/established people in their career, where the other is often considered as an afterthought or add-on. Generating a space for reciprocal learning established everyone as a valuable connection and carrier of opportunities.

⭐️ They used Black-owned cat, where you actually had an opportunity to learn about their businesses. This worked amazingly, especially because so many at the event were locals.

⭐️ @efefruci was so wholeheartedly invested in this event execution and every person making it happen. This translated to a supportive and responsive for everyone involved (based on the overwhelmingly positive perspectives I gathered).

I spoke on the disability in the workplace panel, moderated by @sosaeweka with my fellow panelist @kristinlbower. I always leave after presenting this topic with fulfillment, because soooo many audience members share with me that have never been exposed to a perspective on disability and rest that doesn’t centre capitalism.

And I leave with so much sadness for what people with disabilities, neurodivergent existences, and mental illness continue to navigate as we’re left behind in workplace movements towards “diversity, equity, and inclusion” (that almost always fails to delineate from the root causes of why we have to do that work in the first place).

Both feelings drive my commitment to sharing the softest parts of myself through this work.

Language that has helped me stop apologizing for my bi and demisexuality, because #bisexualawarenessweek.

📱1-2: @advaya.life Aisha Paris Smith’s words on consent as reparative.

📱3: @courtneyahndesign’s affirmations of bisexuality. Because we don’t hear these enough.

📱4: @theexpansivegroup celebrating the great parts of bisexuality. Until reading this I related to bisexuality almost exclusively as something I need to apologize for, and to do everything I can to make partners feel comfortable with it.

📱5: @whatsmybodydoing providing some shared language on what demisexuality can be. Yes, people on the asexual spectrum are just as valid lil bisexuals as the rest 💕

📱6: @theexpansivegroup breaking down different kinds of intimacy. I don’t typically seek all kinds of intimacies from one partner, and this really helped me understand and communicate what I already knew for myself. (Adapted graphic for size)

📱7-8: @thebraincoach on different kinds of boundaries. There are a few more, you can go to their profile to find them. This really helps me establish clear boundaries and expectations when moving between and within connections. (Adapted graphic for size)

📱9: @innerflow_somatics with this concept drop, “kairosclerosis,” which is helping me check myself when I try to pathologize or overthink why I’m happy (read: self-sabotaging behaviour). 

I’ve loved seeing all the bisexual content on my feed this week - happy Bisexual Awareness Week and keep it up 🤗

Anyone who follows my work knows how much I love talking about decolonizing our relationships to time, especially because it’s sooo complex when we put theory into practice. I talked about that in this clip.

I hit my head last week on a squat rack, the hardest I have since my initial bleed. I’m back to light and noise sensitivity, difficulty reading and writing, remembering what I’m saying/doing, intensive brain pain and inflammation, and irritability/significant mood swings. I opened this speech talking about how I’m doing, and when talking about aligning our relationship to time with our health needs I recounted how I wasn’t doing that by being here today. But I find compassion for myself, and I’ll try again tomorrow.

As you’ll find in my language and use of “I statements,” I’m speaking on behalf of myself and within the scope of my own lives experience, privileges, and research. The speech was targeted at post-secondary students, professors, staff, and NGO workers.

Follow @thenapministry (found first from @samanthamatters) for your daily reminders that your rest is revolutionary.

Facts and data are tools to tell stories, but when it comes to residential schools and their living legacies we often get stuck at the tool in non-Indigenous spaces. Rarely is the data humanized in a way that builds a capacity for empathy - consequently contributing to Indigenous Peoples being positioned as the obscure historical “Other”.

Empathy is a skill that can not be fully realized when our truths are clouded by ignorance.

In 2018 when working at the Ontario Ministry of Energy, I was struck by my colleagues’ ignorance of the living legacies of residential schools. I was particularly angered by how that ignorance shaped our provincial policy and program outputs.

So as the youngest and only self-identifying Indigenous person in the office, I asked my ADM to hold a office-wide session on Orange Shirt Day. I knew I needed to do something different to get through to these people.

After having read A Knock at The Door: The Essential History of Residential Schools, and spending time with mostly Anishinaabek and Métis (MNO) knowledge keepers through my other contract work at the time, I started to prepare a somatic engagement activity; I wanted to make these legacies personal and visceral. I wrote a narrative script that walked the audience through a circumstance where a child they love was stolen and put through experiences named in A Knock at The Door. It’s not until the end that they realize what I read aloud was verbatim testimony from survivors.

In closing, I ask them to think of someone in their late 30s. I share that this is about the age of a residential school survivor, because the last school didn’t close until 1995.

While I also share the facts and data, this engagement puts humanity first and continues to catalyze the most immediate shift in people’s worldview and truth that I see in my work.

407 ETR brought me into to do this work this year. Nearly everyone in a packed space was crying. They started making connections to their work and lives. There was an improved capacity for empathy. I’m thankful for people like @itskadeisha who invest in creating space to honour that these legacies affect us all, and we all have a responsibility to them.

Disrupting is an act of love and servitude. Here are some insights I have from building a career through disrupting:

✳️ How do you know when you need to speak up? For me, my heart rate spikes immediately, and that’s a physical cue. Other cues include when I recognize someone else is experiencing harm, but it’s not safe for them to name it; when I’m the only one who looks like me in a room; when there is an absence of any grassroots activists, diverse bodies and experiences; when what is happening goes directly against my values or teachings from my communities. 

✳️ What do you need to care for yourself in the moments following disrupting? I can’t always honour everything I need after disrupting, but I can always find moments - gratitude journaling, walking outside, going on a run or workout - to come back to my body.

✳️ What are the consequences of disrupting? I evaluate and prepare myself for the network, opportunities, and income I compromise by disrupting. This is very important to do. From personal experience, I have never regretted doing this, and disrupting has always attracted the people and opportunities and income that do align with what I want to leave behind as a future ancestor.

✳️ I did a TEDx talk called “How to Engage in Community to Boardroom Activism” on the subject of preparing for activism in institutional spaces when I was 23. You can find it by searching that title or on the TED website.

P.S. This skill translates beautifully as a sports fan 😂 I’m a loud football and basketball fan, and I relentlessly call out refs and players pulling shit (I have unashamedly caused some incompetent refs to consider a career change). I’m also loud when someone does something incredible. Often times women will say ‘thank you, you’re saying exactly what’s going on in my mind, also I love that you know so much about [the sport]!”

And I think in a nutshell, whether it’s as a sports fan or boardroom disrupter, what you share will resonate with more people than you realize.

Colonial worldviews and vegan activism 👉🏽 “I’ve been hesitant to associate myself with the mainstream vegan movement, primarily because I’ve witnessed how it has been shaped by the living legacies of colonialism: White supremacy, extractivism and deforestation, oppression of Black and Indigenous peoples.

No activist is shielded from perpetuating this harm, regardless of their race or ethnic background, and because of this we carry a responsibility to ensure that our activism is informed by realities that go beyond our immediate lived experiences and worldviews.”

More on how I relate to veganism in my bio, “What Veganism Means to Me.” I encourage any vegan to think about putting together something like this that reflections your own relationship to veganism 🤲🏽🌱
