6 Questions for Curious to Veteran Vegans 👉🏽 When I dream about a vegan activist movement I am proud to be a part of, it begins with more vegans being critical of the movement and harmful legacies.

I started my “What Veganism Means to Me” document at the beginning of my vegan journey, and I continue to update and expand it. These are some questions that directed my research and reflection when creating the document:

🌱 What does veganism mean to me?

🌱 How is my commitment to veganism aligned with my values?

🌱 What privileges enable me to choose veganism?

🌱 How have colonialism and capitalism shaped vegan activism, and what it’s responding to?

🌱 What kind of vegans fill my social/information feeds? What kinds of vegans are missing?

🌱 How do I want to execute vegan activism? To what end?

Reflecting on these questions can support your engagement in vegan activism more ethically, and with greater self-awareness. When we’re able to communicate a conscious and intentional relationship to food, we can invite others to do the same.

“What Veganism Means to Me” is in my bio. I encourage any vegan to think about putting together something like this that reflections your own relationship to veganism 🤲🏽🌱

These 4 mindset shifts changed my relationship with chronic pain – @thespooniementor

I’ve been experiencing 7 to 8/10 pain flares the past month, and I found myself coming back to this compassionate resource created by @thespooniementor.

I have endometriosis throughout my intestines, uterus, and ovaries; adenomyosis; chronic pelvic inflammatory disease; ovarian cysts; and pelvic congestion disorder (there’s more but some I forget the names of). I have also been recovering from a severe brain bleed I sustained in 2020. Pain is constant, but the flares put a regular strain on the relationship I have to my body and pain.

Movement (mobility training, yoga, functional strength training, bouldering & climbing, running, hiking), a vegan diet, and anti-depressants have been the only long-term solutions I’ve experienced in making the pain more manageable.

Still, there are days like today where all I want to do is sit in the fetal position. Sit in the fetal position too long though, and the anxiety of work, messages and emails, social relationships, perception of my work ethic, financial loss because I can’t work, parenting responsibilities all hit like a slap to the face, or a constant pressure on my shoulders.

But it’s ok.

“It is safe to rest. My worth is not tied to my productivity. I am enough.”

“My body is innately wise and trying to protect me from a perceived threat.”

“How can I slow down and nurture myself in this moment?”

“I’m allowed to be frustrated. I will continue to advocate for myself and explore solutions.”

(A note when engaging with these - privilege and circumstances inform access to these affirmations 👆🏽 it isn’t always safe to rest, but it’s something I’m working towards.

This is something @thespooniementor does a great job highlighting in their captions and content.)

The gift of exposure - I started going to conferences and gatherings with my mum in my early teens, and exposure to intergenerational and interdisciplinary spaces fundamentally shaped (whether in spite or by inspiration) the adult I’ve grown to be.

My mum was the first one of our family to figure out how to check in to a 4-star hotel, what you need to bring to conferences, how to introduce yourself, how to advocate for our communities and knowledge in institutional spaces. These were gifts she passed on to me, and figuring out *how* to do this was less prominent in my learning journey.

I’ve had to navigate so many aspects associated with my perceived non-belonging in these spaces, racism, ableism, ageism, all the bullshit. And Zyra’s witnessed so much of this, and how I deal with it (which includes using my mom voice, which she particularly enjoys when she’s not the one in trouble 🫢). Zyra will walk onto any stage, go up to any group of people, and she will confidently affirm that she is HERE and deserves to be hahaha.

What two generations of healing work can do.

Zyra’s truths are being shaped and role modeled by the experiences and people she has exposure to through this work. And this gives me a lot of hope. 

The leaders at @foundations.uasu are exactly the kind of people I want Zyra to look up to. Y’all really are doing the WORK in healthy and sustainable ways, and I am so excited to witness how all of y’all continue to serve our communities ✨

Master of Science in Biomedical Engineering, Specializing in Biomechanics and Wearable Technology ✅

@nike’s most prestigious international award in her field in Osaka (typically reserved for PhD students) ✅

Wildly successful practicum at @adidas headquarters in Portland ✅

Multiple-year software research positions at @garmin ✅

Product work with @arcteryx.alberta ✅

+5 years as a basketball player, captain, and assistant coaching with @dinoswbb ✅

For years she’s volunteered hours and hours mentoring and coaching young girls and people in STEM and basketball ✅

And that’s not even CLOSE to half of it.

You will not find a more (annoyingly) humble person than my baby sister. Yesterday we celebrated her walking the stage, and the impressive magnitude of what she’s accomplished in her undergraduate and now postgraduate degrees really struck me. She is not only a leading force at @ucalgary, but quite literally on the global scale of footwear research 🌍👟

If you’re ever looking to highlight, amplify, or work with @reynacrawford, please reach out to her! She’s on LinkedIn. 

From @ucalgary: For her inclusive research investigating the sex-dependent effects of a novel basketball shoe design for basketball players, Crawford, BSc’21, received the Nike Award for Athletic Footwear Research at the Footwear Biomechanics Symposium that took place in Osaka, Japan…

For her award-winning research, Crawford asked basketball players to perform sport-specific movements with and without laterally wedged insoles in their shoes. 

“From there, I collected timed performance and biomechanical data. I made comparisons between males and females with and without the insoles to look at any differences of performance and injury-related variables,” says Crawford. 

The importance of this research, Crawford says, is that it gives insight into whether shoe modifications have useful impact on females and males in an industry where differentiation between the sexes is often lacking. 

“It’s important to acknowledge the sex differences and I hope to improve the quality of footwear for female basketball players, while still ensuring that everybody can benefit,” says Crawford.

A night at @banffgondola Nightrise, an immersive night-time experience at the summit of Sulphur mountain 🏔️

✨ Nightrise is an installation by @momentfactory (another @ancestorsfuture client) in collaboration with @pursuitcollection @pursuitbanffjasper and with leadership of the Stoney Nakoda Nation. It is open from 18 November 2023 to 30 March 2024z

✨ “The Nightrise experience begins as guests step inside the gondola and embark on a multi-sensory journey. At the peak, they can wander through the multi-level summit building and step outside onto observation decks to encounter the magic that only emerges after sundown. Inspired by natural phenomena like cosmic rays and alpenglow, vivid multimedia effects, video projections, and original soundscapes transform the site into a place for exploration and contemplation.”

✨DATE NIGHT: This installation is intimate, and by design encourages you to be present, cozy, and amazed by the natural surroundings. Cuddling spots are plentiful, with campfire and benches strategically places throughout the institutional. There was a great selection of custom cocktails and mocktails, some of which you can drink in an ice-glass at the Nightrise Bar! 

✨FAMILY NIGHT: The kiddos LOVED how interactive this installation is - from floor lights that track your movement to music making, they were busy the entire time. All the options that kept them busy gave the adults that much needed downtime next to the fire.

✨SOLO EXCURSION: I like doing excursions alone sometimes, and this whole experience is very solo-traveller friendly with all the different things to do, read, and learn from.

✨What made me fall in love with this installation was actually what went on behind the scenes; an extensive amount of research was done to prevent light pollution and disruption to the natural ecosystem. The colours of lights and the sounds you hear and create at Nightrise have been carefully selected in alignment with that research.

I highly recommend adding this to your Banff itinerary this year!

comfort food with my comfort person 💕 swipe to throwback 12 years

Lane and I found each other in grade 10 on the Alberta Education Minister’s Student Advisory Council. Every other month we got flown into Edmonton to advise ministers and government staff on provincial educational direction and curriculum implementation.

We went through so much shit in high school, and we are who we are because of it; councils like this were our escape, but Lane made it so much more than an escape. That work became what we love to do, with and for the people we love, and this remains so true today.

@boner.tz feels like home, and I’m so proud of the adults we are today.

This felt sooo far away 2 weeks ago 😩 Some considerations about this wee journey of mine:

☑️ I’ve been practicing pistol squats for over 8 years, so this foundational skill contributed to picking up another squat variation quickly.

☑️ After having a small tear in my MCL from bouldering this past Spring, I started investing more time and intention into my mobility training to prevent future injuries due to hyperextension and… aging 😬 (I enter my last year of my 20s in February).

☑️ I workout 4-6 times per week, 2.5-4 hours a workout. Lower body days consist of dynamic stretching (15min), HIIT (30min), weight lifting (60-120min), abs (15 min), mobility (30-40min), dynamic stretching and yoga (30-40min). I especially target balance and hip and ankle mobility throughout.

☑️ Moving is some of the only time I’m not actively aware of my #chronicpain, so it informs how I use my time and structure my days and work accordingly. 

☑️ I practiced most of the exercises @raphkg recommends in his dragon squat video. I saw a lot of progress when I added various mobility exercises posted to @kneepainaid; I highly advise following the account for regular motivation to move, even if it’s in the living room while watching TV!

☑️ This isn’t perfect, I’m far from the full dragon squat! But, a reason I see progress so quickly is that I film my attempts, watch them back, identify what’s going wrong, and correct accordingly. Often times this leads to more effectively positioning my centre of gravity and hips. (Studying the videos posted on pages like @kneepainaid help me know what I need to look for to correct my form.)

☑️ Starting to train at @evolveroyaloak has been great, the gym has so much turf and equipment to make mobility training easy and spacious.

I was just ecstatic last night when I did dragon squats for the first time (after a couple shots of whiskey and thinking “I’m just going to see how this goes…”). So cheers to that 🥃 and don’t skip mobility!!

Getting to @studentenergy 2023 Summit, an event on the margins of @cop28uaeofficial 👏🏽 What an incredible achievement by young people I’ve had the privilege of admired, loved, and witnessed grow for years. Y’all have come so far.

The journey getting to Abu Dhabi was chaotic but filled with gratitude and smiles thanks to the @studentenergy team and @beautyandthetreatz ♥️🇦🇪

Day 1 of the 2023 @studentenergy summit 🎤🔋

I’m still processing the incredible day. I’ll share my full contributions in a reel in the coming week. Thank you so so so much for the outpour of support and words of gratitude ♥️ I see y’all. I love y’all, so much.

I know there have been some concerns over my safety in the UAE due to the what I said on stage. But I’ve been safe, especially relative to what people are going through every day on the ground. It took a few days to prepare what I shared on stage because I’ve been heated. Too often in the just transition dialogue, we completely fail to acknowledge harm - and our resolutions fail to uproot the root causes of why we need a transition in the first place.

I used my mom voice to get real about colonialism, genocide, the threat of Indigenous relationships to land and the violence that falls upon us consequently when we pose a threat to fossil fuel and natural resource extraction and profit. At no point though, did I think I wouldn’t say what I did; I carry a responsibility and I take it very seriously when I’m offered a platform like this.

While I’ve gotten some written messages, almost all of my feedback was offered in the hours and days after that I spent with the @studentenergy delegates. From Brazil to Mali to Madagascar to Sudan to Palestine to Columbia to USA to Canada to Nigeria and beyond, what y’all reminded me of is that we’re bound by a strength, pain, resilience, and dream for just and sustainable futures. I’ve been in tears. I’ve been heartbroken. I’ve been overwhelmed with joy.

When I get the recording I’ll share my panel contribution here.

With strength and mobility training and LESS bouldering, I’ve seen exponential progress - I get it now. I really try to study bouldering and climbing technique, I follow a lot of coaches, and one piece of advice I was constantly seeing from the experts was DON’T overtrain on the wall.

After a few months of hitting a plateau where I was really struggling to get through C4s consistently - even though I was bouldering 4-5 times a week - I took that advice to heart and started strength and mobility training 5 times a week, and took some time away from the climbing gym.

Today was my first session back after about a month and I was flashing C3s and hitting every C4 I wanted to in one session! A month ago, C4s took 2-3 l sessions before I could finish them, and I wasn’t consistently flashing C3s. And 11 months ago I was a C2 girly, spending 2-3 sessions on C3s!!

As much as the technique training is important, I’m really seeing the benefits of a more balanced approach that builds the strength to finish the routes, and the mobility to prevent injuries 🤙🏽

P.S. Thank you to the people who share that my posts get them out there bouldering and climbing more 🥹 I literally cry every time I hear that. Disrupting the climbing/bouldering bro culture one climb at a time ehhhh. #bouldering #blackgirlsboulder #climbing

Out for 2024: Glossing over ongoing genocides in Palestine, Congo, Sudan, Colombia, Brazil, Hawaii, Canada, and more in climate, energy, and sustainability spaces - ALL spaces.

These panel contributions were made on the opening plenary at the 2023 Student Energy Summit, 31 Nov 2023 in Dubai, UAE. The topic was ‘Building Bridges: Women
Empowerment and Collaborative Approaches for Just Transition.’

“I am not interested in building [a bridge] to a rotting foundation that is destabilized by an understanding of who has a right to existence and who does not, contingent on their facilitating or hindering role in the profit of natural resource extraction and control. 

I am not interested in building a bridge to that foundation.”

In for 2023: Being actively anti-genocide, and coming together to collectively support one another in navigating the ramifications of doing so.

I know many of you follow and trust my work. The contributions you see here were done with a deep commitment to understanding the history, perspectives, and contemporary realities I shared - and how they’re connected across space and time.

Please consider taking some time to watch my full contributions (24min) on YouTube. I spent time contextualizing the “just transition” discourse in colonialism with restorative practice, and I share very practical ways to realize my calls to action.

You can also refer to our @ancestorsfuture anti-genocide statement for a written example of what this can look like, and further learning resources.

These are all in my bio Linktree under “Being Anti-Genocide Stance at SES 2023, Dubai.”

“My ancestors survived genocide. My ancestors survived, and they survived because of a hope, because of a dream, because they could see the impossible. They worked every day to achieve that dream, and to make that dream a reality - where I can sit here today.

And so this idea of dreaming, this idea of seeing a reality where there has been a just energy transition that is radical, that is revolutionary, that is valid.

This is the way I honour my ancestors and everything they survived, and that’s the way I’m honouring the people whoa re going through those kind of atrocities today.”

“What would you be doing if you weren’t working?” has been my virtual backdrop for speeches, training, and meetings for years. Just out of shot has been a collection of my chronic stressors to chip away at. Ritual reminders are what I see when I sit down, and just to my right are seasonal priorities that can help me when I set my daily tasks.

Every January I revamp the boards - my visual cues for maintaining focused balance. Essentially I use an approach affirmations that is visual and daily (rather than said aloud, which doesn’t work for me as well).

This past year I really struggled with my corner, more than I ever have. I learned from that though, to practice self-compassion in routine; it’s ok to take a step back from priorities and rituals BEFORE you burn out.

This year I’m going to try doing revamping my corner seasonally, in a more committed practice. I’m also going to work harder at being in my office physically more during the work week (the thing about having an accountability corner is that if I don’t want to confront my responsibilities, I can close the door and physically avoid them…).

Every year I’ve gotten a little better at holding myself accountable to these affirmations, goals, and priorities. I’ll get a little better this year, too.

From mid-2022 through all of 2023, we (@ancestorsfuture) were challenged with having to actively navigate existing and new trauma in ways that informed the foundation of our work and capacity to do it. From having one of our Founding Directors transition out of the organization; to firing scores of clients who proved to have performative, check-box motives; to the financial strains of being contractors with disabilities and fluctuating working abilities, we have been in a constant cycle of burning out, trying to heal, burning out, trying to heal.

Eventually, in March 2023 this team did some of the hardest things entrepreneurs have to do, took space to REALLY heal and rest, and slowly started to come back to ourselves and each other. After 6 months of space, we started organically coming back to pick up and put the pieces together. Our retreat was a culmination of our willingness to lean into rest and healing, and the collective power of the organizational leadership we’ve all always envisioned for @ancestorsfuture.

In April 2024 we will be relaunching with new visuals, descriptions, and services birthed from all the minds who make up @ancestorsfuture ♥️ For the first time in years, I’m incredibly excited - without any hesitation at all - for what we’re creating and putting out into this world as a collection of incredible entrepreneurs. Of course in the meantime, y’all can still hire us for any of our services. Peep our website (link in bio) for more.

@spiritwindsranch is a ranch nestled in Rocky View County, AB, where the proceeds from their quaint cabin rental are reinvested into their Equine Assisted Learning and other programming that benefits community youth and people with disabilities.

If you’re in the area, check out their programming and volunteer opportunities at spiritwindsranch.ca. 

@ethnicsnax led the search for our @ancestorsfuture retreat accommodations, and our group came to consensus that @spiritwindsranch seemed like the best fit for what we were looking for:

🌾 Access to self-directed land-based activities
🌾 Outside of city limits, privacy
🌾 Access to non-human kin
🌾 A spacious, homey rental that’s family friendly
🌾 Purposeful travel, community building

We found all of this and more, and I highly recommend considering them for your next get away. You can find them on Airbnb, search “Vintage Ranch, Guest Accommodations” (https://abnb.me/jxYVuYEG5Fb).

If you do book, make sure to say hi to Laurel from us and ask for a tour! Laurel is the ranch owner and is a contracted Equine Service Provider for the Municipal District of Rocky View West. She works with thirteen schools in Cochrane, and is an involved and caring host.

We can learn so much about accessibility, inclusion, and healing through arts from cosplay and Otafest that is directly relevant to what we do in policy, government, workplaces, education. The benefit of working across so many sectors is that what we learn from our Arts clients, we bring to our Law clients, for example. The innovation borne from cross-sectoral synergy is incredibly exciting, and fosters deepened appreciation for the value that the Arts can have in all of our lives.

These are moments from #Otafest2023, one of mine and Zyra’s favourite times of the year. I love the friends we’ve made over the years, they really make me love being in Calgary.

From the @gauntletuofc article, “Calgary’s Otafest is as strong as ever for its 25th anniversary”:

“The festival also stayed socially conscious of the many important issues surrounding artists and minorities in the community. With these panels, entertainment was not forgotten, but education was pushed to the forefront as socially important topics were discussed.

An example is Larissa Crawford’s Anti-Racism Panel, in which she discussed how creative work creates transferable and valuable skills that are related to culture. The panel delved into the enduring legacy of a colonized and capitalist experience of time where productivity is seen as more important than honouring our bodies and the seasons, as Crawford put it. Crawford advocated for guests to recognize how racism persists in daily life, and to heal by placing value in creative pursuits and hobbies.

The hundreds of cosplayers at the festival illustrated the truth of Crawford’s words.”

How I make other people feel when I stand in my power, strength, and beauty isn’t a ‘me’ problem…

I’m proud of what I’m able to accomplish as a single disabled mum and entrepreneur. My body is a reflection of choosing 3hr workouts over clubbing and partying; hours of training studying; a lifetime of athleticism; a balanced VEGAN diet; a wicked work ethic; and ancestral gifts.

What about any of that is unprofessional, makes me an undesirable partner, isn’t something to be celebrated? ✨

This picture has sat in my drafts for months because I was concerned about what you would think.

But, I’ve invested too much in my healing journey to freeze in a reverted state of learned anxiety and shame about my body.

So here’s the picture and more. Maybe you’ll get one of those spicier posts outta the drafts too, eh? Remember, it’s not always a thirst trap, you just look like that 💁🏽‍♀️
